Comments_List: By taking Chemistry 134L I learned different ways to construct lab techniques in order to enrich my knowledge of chemistry.
I developed the skill of being able to fine-tune a lab report to meet the demands of a nitpicking professor.
Strong lab taking skills and a good baseline.

This course gives a decent overview of laboratory skills such as titration and pipetting. I learned rudimentary skills in using excel. It also gave me good insight into how to poorly run a college course. Despite the numerous poorly formatted  quizzes, I learned nothing about chemistry. I also learned nothing about writing good lab reports, but learned everything about how to be a petty grader and how to make students unhappy for no good reason.

I can't even say I learned how to write a lab report, because most of that was just filling in the lab report sheet templates that he posts online. There are questions at the end of reports and answering those is just a matter of asking for help from the TA, the professor, or your friends.

I gained knowledge that CHEM 134L is a pre-med weed-out class (and I've heard CHEM 136L is worse, which is the next semester of lab). This course's grading rubric is atrocious, and when I talked to my TA about the grading rubric, she said that she had already discussed it with Dr. G., and that (hopefully) it will change in the future. This course is truly not terrible: the lab reports, although long and tedious, can be banged out in maybe 2 or 3 hours (other reports took 4 hours). However, you can listen to music and start and finish a lab report in 2-3 hours and get a 55/60 points on it. Not much effort goes into the lab reports, but the reports are just tedious, time-consuming, and overall wants to make you drop out. The reason why I say drop out is because this class only awards you .5 credits, but it feels like 1.5 credits: the amount of work (not intellectual challenge) is so much higher than my other courses. Therefore, I now understand why people say "half the credit, double the work" when compared to other courses.

By taking this class, I learned basic chemistry lab techniques and procedures. I also learned how to report observations and formulate them into a lab report. The class also taught me how concepts I learned in CHEM 161 relate to experiments in the lab.

This course when taken with Chem 161 is very helpful by the means of giving better insight to what we talk about during Chem 161 lecture.  The downfall to this course is that it is graded quite harshly.

The course has amazing teaching assistants and a strong sense of community among those who take the course. Those are the only strong points. This course could be improved if the instructor focused more on our learning experience instead of the lab reports and quizzes. I understand that we must be graded somehow but it was so stressful that I was unable to enjoy any of the experiments that we did. Also, this class should be more credits than it actually is. I spent more time in lab than I did any of my other courses (and did just as much work) and I only got 0.5 credits. The class caused me so much anxiety that my body now experiences an automatic stress response whenever I near the point in the week where I had lab.
The lab reports were excessively tedious and didn't reflect the level of knowledge I had on the lab. The labs themselves were engaging

This was my first lab experience and I found General Chemistry Laboratory to be very intimidating.  The quizzes, while a great learning tool, were very difficult for me to perform well on.  Frankly, I was a bit disappointed that there wasn't a workshop to help first time lab takers understand what was expected from the class.  I went in believing that I would be able to catch on quickly, but I was sorely mistaken.  I spent an inordinate amount of time studying for quizzes and working on my lab reports, only to be shocked at my performance on the quizzes.  

As someone unused to the large amount of resources available to me and hailing from a small, under privileged school, I was grossly unprepared for this course.

The only strength of this course is that Dr. G seems to genuinely be interested in chemistry in an abstract way. Also I was fortunate enough to have a good TA who made the course slightly more bearable. The weaknesses are numerous. 40% of the grade rests on 15 minute quizzes comprised of reciting useless information by rote. Dr. G demands an extremely high level of work and organization, while also routinely forgetting to enter student's quizzes into the grade book and then blaming it on them. The lab reports were long and tedious and I learned nothing except for how to spend far too much time fussing with formatting in Word and Excel. The course is supposedly meant to weed out premeds, but is only half a credit freshman year so even does a poor job of that. Instead it just routinely ruined my day. It goes without saying that this course should only be taken as a requirement.
The course is poorly taught and the grading is harsh. There is not much feedback given on the lab reports either.
The course was very time consuming. It seemed like there was a greater emphasis on the format of assignments than improving lab skills.

The grading seemed a bit harsh at first; when I received my first lab report I was surprised at the grade, but I was more confused about what went wrong. I did meet with Dr. G, and he was very helpful in clearing up my confusion. My grades also improved as I improved. Perhaps the course could be presented in a more friendly way; lots of people told me I wouldn't enjoy the course (but I did) and I think that's because the course comes across as scary to some. If the course were presented more as an interesting study of experimental science, it might be more enticing, and ultimately more rewarding for students who otherwise see it as a source for a lot of work and stress.
The grading, particularly of lab reports, is unnecessarily harsh. The TAs are fantastic
This class isnt too hard if you know how to finesse it. Dont let it put too much stress into you and youll be fine. The grading of lab reports can get excruciating though.

There was a good range of experiments that helped to reinforce chem topics. The lab portion of the class was fine. However, the amount of work that we were expected to do outside of class was unreasonable, and getting a good score on many of the lab reports was often unattainable except for a very small number of students. Students were putting in the same amount of work that you would for a 1 or 1.5 credit class.

Strengths: TAs are very helpful, as are pre-lab lectures. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes pre-lab quizzes addressed information that was not addressed before.

The quizzes in this course were great at showing if the student understood the subject. Nevertheless, the curve, the grading, and the way the labs are done is not optimal. I do not think that this course taught me how to write lab reports in a better way as there was always a template. Moreover, formatting "errors" on the reports negatively impacted the grade to an unnecessary point.

The TFs and Dr. G really want you to succeed, and will help with lab reports if you have any questions but you have to ask for help if you want to do well. Some of the questions and assignments were ambiguous to the point that they were impossible to answer without asking what they were really looking for. Overall, the class prepares you very well for the practical and to use these basic lab skills in the future.

The course has a clear structure to it and is very easy to follow. However, I think the quizzes rely too much on memorization. That information tested on the quiz is not necessarily important in order to learn the scientific concepts of the week.

Strengths--concepts were interesting, if poorly explained.
"Points of Improvement"--shortened pre lab lectures, better explained lab manuals, stop grading on the purpose of an experiment in quizzes, more clear feedback on lab reports (not just "bad" or "wrong" or "missed the point." This above all illustrates a lack of care towards the course).

This course has a number of areas where it could be improved. First of all, I believe there is too great an emphasis on titrations, a skill my TA admitted was not that commonly used in labs. Secondly, the course could be improved by using modern pipets. The course currently has us using suction bulbs rather than micro pipets or easier handheld scrolling pipets (not entirely sure what they are called). Considering there was a big emphasis on both precision and accuracy, the equipment we were given made achieving both those aims more difficult for no real reason. Thirdly, I don't really see the point of the lab reports in their current form. They don't reflect the format of published scientific papers and instead become more like harshly graded worksheets. I would encourage the course to consider reducing the number of lab reports and add a component where we take time to learn about how scientific papers work and are formatted.
Grading is for the most part fairly arbitrary, I feel like the grade comes more from nonsensical formatting issues rather than understanding and engaging with the chemistry concepts.

The strengths: students are able to do actual experiments and get a feel for what science in the real world is like. 

Weaknesses: the lab reports are graded very harshly; it is very easy to mess up and very easy for points to be deducted. Also, some lab reports took an extensive amount of time to complete. The amount of time and effort invested into the class is not reflected by how much credit the class is worth.
Long class period, and the lab reports were tedious. Strengths? I guess some of the experiments were interesting, but more so towards the end of the semester.

This class is my favorite class that I have taken so far. I think the amount of independence and support given to students in perfect balance. It really pushes you past your comfort zone while not moving too fast for you to learn. I think that sometimes the quizzes are unnecessary, they never helped me learn and only seemed like busy work to fill in our grades. I would much prefer a pre-class write up or something else instead.

The course is strong in providing us with a background in chemical laboratory skills. However, this course could be improved if stress was reduced a bit by not having the entire course based on points and averages and having so many assignments/assessments. I also didn't really like the idea of makeup week and how if you get above a certain percent error in a lab you must come back to redo the lab for several trials until you improve your accuracy. I think that perhaps it would be better if we can do more labs and drop a lab/quiz to reduce stress and make the course more enjoyable for everyone. Also, sometimes feedback was not so good as on labs when they return it for some questions they just say "WRONG" instead of telling us why or giving an answer key that explains our errors.

This course was a lot of busy work, especially in matters that seemed inconsequential. For example, it took us ages to "do math" on word, whereas it would have been much better to just write out the equations on a printed out sheet.
I found the grading to be extremely harsh.
I think the course places a little too much emphasis on being meticulous about small things rather than focusing on the big picture concepts that are being learned.

The lab exposure is useful, but it is done in such a high-stress environment that the benefit could be questioned. The lab quizzes cover material that does not line up with CHEM 161, so the students with more of a prior chemistry background have a significant advantage. Be prepared to be tested on memorization of chemical equations and formulas.

This course seems to unfairly penalize students for minor mistakes which detracts from student learning. Often times an extreme amount of points are taken off points/lab reports for minor reasons, which makes students frustrated and feel like no matter what they do they can't succeed. It could be improved by fairer grading and a more comfortable learning environment.

This course goes over a variety of different labs that are both interesting and thought provoking. Some of the quizzes were sometimes were sometimes more tricky than they needed to be, or the information was not given in a manner that was useful for studying. Also, some of the feedback on lab reports was not the most useful at times.

This course is a LOT of work for just a half credit, and the lab reports are pretty challenging. Grading can be very nitpicky and subjective. Your TA can make or break your experience. The weekly quizzes were pretty pointless and strangely difficult. It doesn't help your learning at all and just makes the class more stressful. Not only can the questions be obscure, but there is also a time crunch on some of them. There isn't much you can do to prepare except pray for mercy.
The grading was unfair
Weakness: Dr. G

Strengths: forces you to learn, well-organized

Weaknesses: the grading was odd, you either failed or did well. Everyone was more worried about their grade. If it wasn't curved, i think everyone would care more and do better, (and collaborate).
This course was very stressful, and I don't really feel I learned much chemistry from it.

The strengths are that the weekly exposure to new experiments improved my skills in the lab and taught me chemistry in a hands on manner. I feel like the lab helped me understand concepts of Chemistry 161 that I would have otherwise not understood fully. However, the only way to lose points in the class are through format on lab reports and lab quizzes. I feel like this doesn't represent your knowledge of the material and creates unnecessary stress in the class, but I understand that the class cant have a 100% A rate.
Well run but really tough grading

I think that class is very self-directed. This is both good and not-so-good. Good in the sense that students really have a high level of engagement with the material and invest a lot into understanding. And not-so-good in that the course can be overwhelming at first. Either way, I feel that I've learned a lot from chemistry lab.

Grading in this course is harsh and  inconsistent. Sometimes I would lose points on quizzes for things that my friends did not.  Also, this class is a lot of work and should be worth more than a half of a credit.
The class material did not line up with Chem 163L's course material, so a lot of 134L was catching up. The quizzes in this class were weighted a little too much.

Strengths: the course has a clear syllabus that is provided beforehand, so you know what is coming next. The TAs are mostly accessible and helpful, both during the experiment as well as after. I learned a lot of basic chemistry lab skills.
Weaknesses: The course's focus on attention to detail made the process of writing lab reports very tedious, so writing lab reports often took a long time.

This course caused so much anxiety for me this past semester. The lab manuals tend to be disorganized, not making much sense until you are in the lab itself. Additionally, grading can seem to be arbitrary and unnecessarily harsh. Only really take this class if you must.

The quizzes counted for a much greater percentage of the grade than one might expect so do not neglect studying for them. The greatest weakness of the course is the extremely strict grading because this makes things very competitive and nearly impossible to enjoy oneself.

I think this class was very valuable and had a very positive experience in this course. The lab professor was very available for help, which made it much easier to succeed in the class. However, we had pre-lab quizzes each week which often included minute details that were very difficult to remember even if I had spent a significant amount of time preparing for the lab.

The class was well-strucutured but I wished that the lab report was not heavily focused on grammatical and technological errors. Instead, it should be focused on whether or not students understand the concepts behind the experiment.

A strength of this course was that it provided good background information before every experiment, which provided a solid foundation before completion of an experiment.
The course could improve with more succinct instructions in the lab manuals, as students were often confused with instructions in paragraph form and would often make mistakes in the lab.
the course is ridiculously demanding for no reason.
The class is somewhat stressful because of the weekly quizzes, but besides that I loved it. I felt the hands-on experience was fun every week and it only improved my knowledge of chemistry.

Strengths: Dr. Gs explanations at the beginning of each lab were very helpful and clear. 
Weaknesses: This should not be a half credit course - I spent more time on it than most of my other classes in the beginning of the semester. I feel like also there was too much packed into one lab period - the expectations were so high that one was constantly frazzled.
I like how this course had a set schedule and weekly routine of assignments, lectures, quizzes, experiments, and lab reports. However, some of the assignments were entered into Canvas slowly.

This class is very time consuming and emotionally draining. The lab reports are extensive and graded harshly. However, Dr. G is willing to answer any questions you may have. The class is a lot of work and many students complain about it. The pre-lab quizzes are awful and are often based solely on memorization of lab instructions.

The course was comprehensive and covered important material, however, I found that I spent more time worrying about the meticulous details in the lab reports than I spent trying to understand concepts and making sure that I was applying my skills correctly.
It is pretty stressful, and the teachers don't do anything to relieve the stress surrounding the course.
Unengaging, I felt like I wasted my mondays.

Strengths: Dr. G. really knows what he's saying. He put time and effort into preparing the labs, which is always evident in the procedures. He always makes you ask questions and challenges you to learn more and to think more critically, which I loved. 

Weaknesses: THE GRADING. Oh my the grading. How haphazard what is going on. At times I felt like random numbers would just be assigned as my grade because I didn't get feedback on how I could've improved or what I did wrong. I wish there were more transparency and clarity about the grading.
Grading sometimes unfair but very organized and well-structured.
I thought the pre-lab lectures were very helpful. There was adequate time to finish the labs, and the lab reports themselves were straight-forward and usually easy to understand.

I thought that this course did a great job exposing students to a wide array of lab skills and techniques, as well as supplementing information learned in chemistry class. My one complaint is that the rubrics in the class were often very harsh and even if only minor mistakes were made, it would significantly bring down my grade, which made the course significantly more stress-inducing for me.
It's a fine course, but the fact that everyone does really well and then we're graded on a negative curve really sucks ass and is incredibly discouraging.
The grading is super harsh and unfair. Be prepared to spend a crazy amount of time on each lab report. Not even difficult material most times, just tedious work.

The strengths of this course are that you learn to very basic chemistry lab techniques and tasks very very precisely and accurately.  You learn to construct a basic lab report, check your work in great detail, and show up to lab on time with all your equipment.  You learn to fear the consequences of failing Dr. G's expectations.  You gain some familiarity and level of comfort within a chemistry lab.

The weaknesses of this course are fairly well-known: 4 hours is an awfully long time to devote to a half-credit course, it's easy to lose points on lab reports for extremely minor errors, and the final is very much all-or-nothing.
Pre-class lectures are comprehensive introductions to course material and labs. Graded lab reports provide very little support for improvement.

Strengths:
-good exposure to basic chem lab practices
-Dr. G is good at teaching the concepts behind how the experiments work

Weaknesses:
-Overemphasis on perfection (on lab reports) as opposed to understanding the concepts 
-harsh grading curve

It initially seems that everything you have to do to do well in this class is laid out for you on a silver platter, but you soon find out that this is not the case. It all seems easy until you get your lab reports back riddled with unexplained point reductions for minor errors (i.e. significant figures) and things that shouldn't even be considered errors like formatting preferences. More transparency is needed regarding how lab reports are graded.
Lots of high pressure situations considering the weekly quizzes and the demand for accurate results
The fact that there is a curve and that the average is very high makes everything very stressful.

Dr. G make this course far too stressful. Instead of constructing things in a manner that encourages you to improve, he destroys your grade over insignificant aspects of experiments and lab reports; in doing this, he fails to see the larger point at hand and to help us truly learn what we need to know. Also, the amount of time devoted to the lab reports and preparing for the pre lab quiz is far too much to justify this only being .5 credit. I spent more time working on this than I did for any full credit course. He is also very condescending and difficult to approach.

I enjoy working hands-on, so I liked performing the experiments in this course. I learned a lot from the variety of experiments. Lab reports do take a lot of time and care, and I think it would have been nice to have gotten more clear feedback on how we could have improved.

This course is very rigorous and Dr. G expects the utmost precision from his students. The weekly labs and labs reports force students to understand the concepts and adeptly apply them. It is a lot of work, but Dr. G is so meticulous that I have nothing bad to say about the course.

Definitely I didn't like that you can only score a 60/60, 55/60, 45/60, or 30/60. This created a lot of anxiety for me in terms of making sure I didn't get a 45. It was also unfair that some TF's gave a 65/60 while others were more harsh. The lab quizzes are rough--make sure you really really study the lab manual. Dr. G is very fair though in not asking questions that he didn't touch on in the pre-lab lectures.
From all the people in higher levels of chem, I have heard that nothing we do in this class is relevant to other labs, because they don't titrate anything.

The main weakness of this class is that that reports are graded harshly. However, to counter that, a strength is that each pre-lab lecture goes extremely in-depth which prepares you for the lab itself.
The course is rigorous, but the lab report grading method is ridiculous. I felt like no matter how hard I tried to do well on them, I still got back 45/60 every time.
strengths are you do get to do your own labs, so that helps. Weaknesses are the tough grading on the lab reports. The lab reports are graded for the most part unfair.
Lab days are long and the reports often feel tedious but I am not sure exactly how to change that. I think the labs we do are important basic labs that are needed in an intro class.
I like the way that the course is set up. I like the experiments and the all of the help that both the instructor and the Teaching Fellows provide. There were no major weaknesses of the course.
i think the environment can be a little less stressful

The labs are always explained very thoroughly during each pre-lab lecture which helps to facilitate understanding of what a student is actually required to do. However, for lab reports it can be a bit more confusing since it can be more difficult to contact a teaching fellow or Dr. G so you are left more to figure it out alone.

Honestly, the class is tedious. This course should inspire students, should make them ask questions and want to learn more. I don't think it accomplishes that. Instead, students wonder how on earth it's possible to lose so many points on a simple sig fig error. I'm sorry for the harsh words. I just think that the class has tremendous potential. It's a pity that it's not interesting, not intellectually stimulating, and not fun.

This course is effective in teaching lab skills, but the level of harshness to which it is graded is often completely insane and this can be disheartening. On the weekly quizzes, it was often near impossible to score well if one had not gone through and memorized certain facts from the lab manual beforehand (something which is not at all necessary in order to effectively and safely perform the actual lab). And on the weekly lab write ups the grading by Dr. G was often completely subjective. Points were taken off for his absurd personal preferences (which we were never notified of) such as using lines instead of tick marks to mark a graph's scale, or placing all data points on the same graph vs. on two different graphs (the preference for this changed with every lab, and was NOT stated in the instructions). My grades on lab reports had no correlation with how hard I worked on them, and seemed to be completely based on how lucky I was to match Dr. G's preferences of the week.
There is no strength in it. It could be improved in every aspect. It is long, it is harder than necessary
This course teaches you many lab techniques and methods that are outdated and are no longer used in modern laboratories. I feel that the course syllabus and curriculum should be updated.

I really liked how the class built upon itself in terms of the difficulties of the lab. However particularly for the lab quizzes I would have liked if the labs matched up with the lectures for Chem161.

I really did not enjoy this class. It was more work than I had for other full credit classes when this was only a half credit. I spent a lot of time on the lab reports and found myself worrying if my spacing was right, or if I had used a specific word or not, or if my graph was perfect, more than I found myself worrying about the concepts at hand. Furthermore, the quizzes were good, but sometimes I found myself learning the material later in the week, and because my lab day was Monday, I didn't have a chance answering some of the questions. In addition, the class did not pay attention to when the tests were scheduled in Chem 161. I would always have lab followed by a chemistry exam. Each and every Chem 161 exam was on the same day as my lab. I feel like the tests in 161 should not be all on one day of the week in the future to avoid this problem.
The labs should probably correspond more to the material in 161/163 so that the information we're expected to know on the quizzes isn't brand new.

The strength of this lab course is that it challenged students to understand how meticulous labs and their respective reports are. As for its cons, I believe that the organization of the course makes for a competitive environment among students.

The strength of the course is that you certainly learn a lot: techniques, and how to handle lab materials. In terms of weaknesses, I disagree with the grade weighing. I felt that quizzes should not have been worth so much considering how many questions on the quizzes involved straight memorization.
Dr. G is intense.

Strengths: My TA was great and shes the only reason why I didnt drop the course.
Weaknesses: literally everything else
This course was very interactive and engaging, and allowed students to flexibly work on all skills involved in the experiments.

This course is very ambiguous with its expectations and also at times unfair. This course was supposed to give us practical knowledge towards the information that we were learning in our chemistry class, but instead we ended up covering material sporadically that did not cover what we learned in class. This in turn led to quizzes over material we had never learned. It could be improved by getting rid of the quizzes or having the quizzes relate to material taught in chemistry lectures and not random chemistry topics that have no yet been taught in class.

I hate the picky grading. I would put hours into my report and get marked down on stupid small things (such as not using passive past tense) that did not effect my report overall and friends who put in like an hour's work got better grades.
There is very much a cut-throat attitude in the grading of the lab reports and the quizzes of this course which make the effort almost seem not worth it.

Strengths: Taught basic laboratory skills well and reinforced concepts we learned in lecture.

Weaknesses: Terribly stressful, terrible environment for learning, and feedback from Dr. G is extremely unhelpful.
The strengths were that I learned more about basic chemistry laboratory principles. The major weakness was the way in which lab reports were done and graded.
It is very well taught. The lab reports seem unnecessarily long, but they are meant to be that way for optimal leaning.
A strength of this course was the organization. Instructions were clear and easy to follow and there was always an instructor or TA available to answer questions. A weakness was inadequate feedback.
Weaknesses: Very strict grading, lots of points lost for minor errors, pretty unforgiving in that sense but also the strength as it is a brutal teacher sometimes.

The course was graded very strictly and the rubric was convoluted/not disclosed. Quizzes could be confusing at times. The course was well structured  in terms of labs and reports, however, and the TAs were patient and helpful.

The course was strong in that it taught me more about basic laboratory procedure. I completely appreciated the effective lectures from Dr. G and the great instruction from my TA. However, there are many aspects of Chemistry 134L that I believe need to be changed in order to make the course better and to benefit more students. 

First of all, the fact that there is only one "General Chemistry Lab" for both Chem 161 and 163 students caused several issues. For many 161 students taking chemistry for the first time, Chem 134L covered completely new material, while myself and other 163 students were left rehashing old material. This divide in the course left the professor and the TAs attempting to teach students at very different levels of preparedness and was quite ineffective.

Secondly, the course was not set up well to actually facilitate learning. Before each period, we needed to read the lab manual and study the material for the upcoming experiment. In the beginning of the period, we had a lecture on the material we read and then were immediately quizzed on it after the lecture. It would have been far more effective to learn in the lecture, have time to read and study before the next period, and then be quizzed on said material. While the quizzes were not extremely difficult or in any way unfair, they could have covered deeper concepts or encouraged actual learning if they were set up differently.

In addition, the grading of the class was extremely confusing and unintuitive - often unfair. No real grading rubric was ever given to the students, so we were in the dark as to how lab reports were being scored. Halfway through the course, our TA gave us a rudimentary rubric that was even more confusing - it marked off in certain "categories" that would add together certain "shortcomings" to count up total "problems." I have never seen such an odd grading system, as it created extremely strange weightings for certain categories. Stranger still, the only possible grades on lab reports were 60/60, 50/60, 45/60, 30/60, and 0/60, according to this rubric - nothing in between. Later in the course, I was told that even this rubric was scrapped and that some other system was being used, but we were never told what this system was. I simply wish that we were told how we were being graded. One final note on grading - the vast majority of points seemed to be taken off on strange aspects of the reports. I acknowledge that report formatting is important. However, I was very confused that, for example, using the present tense and passive voice just once in a ten-page report warranted being marked off 5 points for grammar. We were also never given clear expectations on how the "Purpose" sections of our reports were being grades, and it became common to lose points for aspects of the report that would have been easy if expectations were made clear.

Finally, and this is less important, but many of the experiments conducted in the lab were mundane and tedious. I completely understand that many students in this course are new to the lab environment and that all experience-based learning is valuable. However, one particular experiment had us doing what were essentially 8 almost identical titrations in one period. It was repetitive and unnecessary. Another experiment had us swirling, by hand, a flask containing a small amount of liquid and metal shavings, for a minimum of twenty minutes to cause a reaction. This was then repeated for a total of three times, taking up at least 1 hour out of the 4 hour lab period. Minor issues compounded like this made Chem 134L far less effective than I think it could have been.

The experiments are fairly simple and easy to understand, and they cover a lot of ground that is useful for other science classes. The questions asked in the lab reports are very clear and for the most part encourage a good understanding of the procedures that were covered in the experiments. More specific feedback on the lab reports would be helpful, however.

The course is mostly busy work--lab reports take up to 7 hours to write up but the bulk of this time is not actual learning. Maybe 1 hour is spent on calculations and extension questions, the rest is spent formatting the work on Microsoft word, which takes forever. Given the inspirational quality Chemistry can have, it is disappointing that this course takes such a basic, boring approach and forces students to invest huge amounts of time in the formatting of lab reports and making graphs instead of trying new, exciting experiments or thinking deeply about the reactions taking place.

The strength was the class was well organized. The main weakness was that the lab reports were graded very ambiguously, and too much emphasis was on formatting issues such as significant figures. I believe that this takes away from the gaining of useful chemistry knowledge.
Harsh grading, both a pro and a con, makes you more diligent but even tiny mistakes are penalized harshly
A weakness is the tedious, long lab report.

Strengths: gets students familiar with lab
Weaknesses: high stress during labs, not very clear preparation before lab quizzes

I really did not enjoy being tested on material that I was lectured on that same day. It might be beneficial to do the lecture for a lab the week before. The grading was also very constraining, where each error, no matter the error, was 5 points off. Maybe doing something more along the lines of a case by case grading where a small sig fig error isn't the same grade reduction as not an meeting an entire question.

I think this course definitely teaches you lab techniques well.

The way lab reports are graded is quite strange and not really conducive to student learning, in my opinion. I think it would make sense to grade them normally, with a rubric, instead of taking off 5 points for each type of mistake. 

I also don't like the format of the lab practical. I feel like it's too easy for a student to do everything correctly and carefully and get above a 1% error for their results, which doesn't seem fair.

strengths: each lab is very structured and the class is generally very organized
weaknesses: comments on lab reports for lost points are few and don't provide information to how to make the labs better

Strengths included that the experiments were very interesting. Weaknesses include that the grading was not very clear and straightforward. In other words, it wasn't entirely clear what one could improve upon when writing their lab reports.
The weekly prelab lectures and quizzes were extremely helpful in preparing me to carry out the experiments.
I think if more useful laboratory skills were taught and if the class ran more efficiently, the course could be improved significantly.
There was very little conceptual preparation for the labs. The instructions were always very clear.
There is a LOT of variation between TF's. That needs to be adjusted for.
This course gives a good foundational overview of laboratory procedures like accurate measurement and careful use of equipment.

This course did a good job marrying abstract chemistry concepts with technical lab experiments. The information provided on how to understand the underlying science of experiments and how to use tools was comprehensive and educational. One weakness of this course was that when we ran into errors, there was not much information on how to troubleshoot or trace our steps back to find the source of the error. Instead, the TAs usually encouraged us to just restart, sometimes without us even knowing what went wrong to prevent future errors.

Strengths of this course include the pre-lab lectures in which the material within the lab was discussed and explored, as well as the feedback from TAs on student lab reports. Weaknesses of this course include the lack of overlap between material in Chem lab 134L and Chem 161 in various labs.
The quizzes were often simple but irritating
The class is very well planned out but it feels very impersonal.
The prelab quizzes were very stressful especially when topics covered in lab were more advanced than what we learned in general chem lecture.

strengths: clear, predictable, routine class and assignment set-up
weaknesses: the grading curve

This course gave a lot of practice with lab techniques and writing lab reports which will definitely help in the future. It was also really nice that the course allowed us to practice for the final exam so that we would not be worried about it the day of.

I faced several issues during this course that unfortunately were not resolved. Firstly, there appeared to be some sort of technical issue that prevented me from accessing the comments on my lab reports on the Canvas. I was not the only student who faced this issue. I was told to go to office hours in order to receive the comments, but this was not always convenient for me. I take responsibility for not having gone to office hours, but I do recommend and request that this issue be addressed for future students so that they can easily access their comments. 

Secondly, there were certain issues with the final exam. When I was preparing the solution in the final exam, I had to use the analytical balance in order to find the mass of the powder. (Note that I was using the balance much after most of the other students, since I had begun my lab time doing other preparations.) However, the analytical balances appeared not to be working correctly as the readings kept going lower and lower, even after I grounded myself and tried again. I asked my TA Yizhou Zhao to have a look because I was not certain why this was happening. He watched me working and also commented that it was "weird" that the analytical balances were behaving in this manner. I think it is most likely that this was the cause of the error in my value in the end (since the titration values were extremely close, and less likely to be the major source of error.). I cannot be certain whether error in my value was due to other mistakes I made or whether I myself was doing something wrong with the analytical balance, but I do think that this issue with the equipment was probably a major contributor to the error. I would just request in the future, just in case, to be very careful about the equipment for the final exam and to have a system to address and record student complaints about the equipment during the exam.


Other than these issues, the course was very well organized and structured, and should probably stay as it is.
I do not like how the course is graded in terms of curving and scaling. It seems unfair. However, everything else is fine.
The course seemed very focused on small details rather than more overall understanding of content

Some strength are that the hands on expierence that one gets from taking this course. Also is runs at a similar pace as General Chemistry I so concepts are reinforced in lab. Some weaknesses include there being no direction during lab or in writing lab report when you are taking a lab early in the week. TA's aren't prepared.
Very strict grading. Learned a lot in the lab. Tough pre-quizzes.
It's very long and often gets boring, especially when one needs to repeat the same experiment multiple times.

You do learn a lot of basic lab skills but the course is very long and Dr, G is pretty intimidating. The lab reports also take a very long time especially for a half credit course. I found the course to be very high stress.

We spend more hours in class and spend more time working for this class than for most of our other courses, yet it is only worth half a credit.
Too many labs. Very tedious, but in an unpleasant way.
We have no idea how our lab reports are corrected.

This course provided a solid introductory overview of skills used in a chemistry laboratory and the lectures prior to lab help explain the context and application of what we were going to do in lab. I do not think the pre-lab quizes were beneficial or increased this understanding in any way.
I enjoyed the intellectual challenge of the course, but it seemed that the course was extremely unorganized at times.
The course bettered my understanding of  laboratory skills. One weakness of the course was that the lab reports were extremely long and tedious.
The quizzes before each lab were a little unreasonable in my opinion. Many times they required you to basically just memorize everything in the powerpoint, which I didn't find helpful or reasonable.

I think this is just a difficult course in general- labs are rarely this rigorous in high school. This class places emphasis on the results as well as the process, stressing the importance of accuracy. Of course, that's science. I will be honest that at first I really did not enjoy this course, and it caused me a lot of grief and anxiety. But I'm not someone to blame the course itself for my difficulties, just because the course is hard. I did find the grading harsh, with too many points taken off for small errors. It was frustrating that one error in a section counted as much as 5 errors in the same section. If one tiny error got me points off for the entire section, why did I spend so much time fretting over it? I could've completely flubbed it and been in the same spot. But if I don't get introduced to that standard now, when will I? Science in the laboratory is about accuracy, and learning to be careful. I was able to get gradually better over time, and that matters most to me.

This course's biggest strength is the experience that you gain. By the end of the course, I felt much more comfortable pipetting and preparing solutions. It's incredibly stressful because of the structure, though. Lab reports are graded harshly, so it's important to read over multiple times, painstakingly looking for a single error that could turn an A into a B (or worse). The practical final requires the same sort of razor-sharp focus, which is good for the future but quite difficult in the moment. The biggest weakness of this class is the emphasis on busywork.

Let us start off with the strengths: this course introduces you to basic lab technique, and you can have fun suffering together in lab with your lab partner and members of your lab group while doing the lab. Honestly, try and make lab fun, and it will not be that bad. However, I was gifted with the amazing TF Staci Hill, whom made lab so much more tolerable and enjoyable. However, the weaknesses outweigh the strengths: this course is poorly designed (especially in reference to the grading rubric). The grading rubric is convoluted and makes no sense. However, if you go to Dr. G.'s office hours, you will probably get a 60/60 on each lab report (although no one says anything about going to office hours). Also, this class is graded on a curve, which means the average grade (be it median or mean) is a B or B+, and then he will inflate AND DEFLATE your grade depending on how you match up to the average score. Another weakness of this course is that you meet once a week FOR FOUR HOURS (1-5pm on any selected day M-F). And please do not pick friday labs unless you have to: it just makes your weekend that much shorter. Do not take this course if you do not have to, it will only be pain and suffering for no reward (except staining your clothes with potassium permanganate or getting a 25/60 on your final).

I thought the labs were always well structured and planned well. I thought the reports we could have done more of the thinking ourselves (doing the calculations ourselves) so the focus would be more on understanding the labs.
The weaknesses are the lab reports and I dont like the quizzes those can really get you

I felt as though some of the quizzes were unfair and there was no real way you could study them. Also having to memorize a huge long chemical equation did not seem fair. 
I also felt as though the lab reports were very unfairly graded. If you made only a couple mistakes your grade would drop a whole letter grade. I thought grading throughout the TAs and Dr. G was vastly different.

It was a very difficult class for me which was a blessing and a curse. I learned very quickly, but sometimes at the expense of my grades. I definitely had to learn from my mistakes multiple times and it was frustrating that I wasn't always doing as well as my peers.
The class was organized very well and my TA was great. Dr.G was great at responding to questions.

Strength: Focus on the important techniques and processes of basic chemistry which is fundamental knowledge for success in other classes

Weakness: Lab reports are strictly graded and points can be taken off for aspects not in the grading manual

This class can be stressful, as it requires entirely hands-on work. However, I think this is essential to being able to carry out experiments in a lab environment. By giving students almost full independence in the lab, it provided an opportunity to take charge in the lab and learn by trial and error. A weakness of this class was the weekly quizzes. I felt they were unnecessary, and could have been replaced by a quiz that focused on lab conduct instead of chemistry content that was taught in an entirely different class.

The strength of this course was that it provided hands-on experiments that related to some of the content discussed in the General Chemistry lecture. The weakness of this course is that it's a half-credit class with twice the work. While labs are very interesting, the lab reports are tedious to write. While it is structured, and students are informed of the type of information/data that should be included, lab reports are very time consuming and are often graded with a lot of nitpicking (including grammar errors), so it can be difficult to tell what the grader wants. I would suggest changing the way lab reports are graded, such as not taking off 5 points for a sentence with bad grammar, and focusing more on providing feedback that help students improve on writing their reports.

The post-lecture quizzes asked ridiculous questions that required students to have equations or information memorized that we were never told to even study. Dr. G's lab report rubric was also ridiculous and he was unnecessarily anal-retentive about very small details. If you weren't exactly right, an entire section would be marked wrong, no matter how well you explained yourself or whether your answer was also correct. If it wasn't Dr. G's way, it was wrong.
Definitely improved my note

The strengths of this course were the lectures before lab; those helped clear up a lot of questions before even setting foot in the lab.

The weaknesses of this course are that the lab report sheets are often rife with mistakes and require revisions/corrections. One thing in particular I disliked about the procedural sheets was that procedures were never given directly and often required close reading to decode what procedures were. I understand that this might be a method to get us to read the material closer and learn more, but to have this kind of procedure sheet in LAB makes lab work incredibly tedious and necessitated me to write my own separate procedure sheet. Now, yes, this probably taught me how to make my own procedure sheet, but it was frustrating every week to say the least.

The grading system is very confusing, I still don't quite understand what is happening. I've known about what my grade would be at throughout the semester, but apparently the curve on this grade can lower it based on what other people get which I think is completely unfair. If someone earns an A, a curve should lower them to a B.

I took CHEM 163 along with this course, but I didn't feel like any of the things we learned in CHEM 136L were applicable to my chemistry course. I didn't like how divorced from each other the two courses were, and I think the lab could be improved if there were two versions of it, one for each intro chemistry class, and they complemented these chemistry courses better. 

Sometimes it felt like the experiments that we did were made to be longer than they needed to be in order to fill the lab period. Some of them could have been completed in shorter periods of time if they had been designed a little differently, so it felt like they were stretched out unnecessarily just so they would take us the whole lab period. 

The course could also be improved if we received more feedback on our lab reports. In most cases were I missed points on my report, there were no comments explaining what I should have done differently or what was wrong about what I wrote. If I wanted to understand what I should have written, I had to come to Dr. G's office hours. For small mistakes, it would be much better and help us write better lab reports if Dr. G and the TAs gave short explanations when they graded our reports.
It was just very very boring. I feel it could be improved by doing more interesting experiments relevant to real life.

The strengths of the course are the consistencies of Dr. G with the course material learned and how it follows the Chemistry 161 curriculum. The weakness is the seemingly impossible grading of the lab reports and the varieties of grades given based on the TA.
There is not a lot of feedback and grades are pretty random. The lab reports could be very difficult at times.

The biggest strength of the course is the pre-lab lecture. Professor G used this time as an opportunity to reinforce the material presented in the manual and clarify any questions and concerns that students had. The only weakness of the course is that there was a lot of material that was presented in the example sections of the lab manuals. The lack of reinforcement in the examples made it more difficult to do well on the quizzes. There were often several steps that needed to be followed to answer the question well and I found significant difficult in this area.

Although this course was excellent in set up ( prelab lecture before actual lab), it often was my major form of stress. The harsh grading and incredibly long lab reports were a bit challenging. Nonetheless, I do believe my Teaching Fellow helped a ton, and perhaps it's good to be exposed to this cut throat environment. I wish it didn't make me so anxious though.
More closely connected with the gen Chem lecture woukd be an improvement

The lab reports for this course are possibly the worst I have ever written, not because of the content of the experiments (which is basic at most) but because of the highly prescriptive, badly designed, mandatory lab report sheets which are difficult to understand and use. The same can be said for the experiment information sheets which are long and wordy (instructions are written in paragraphs rather than bullet points, for example), often unnecessarily repeating the same information, and leaving little room for the student to actually understand the theory behind the experiment. There is essentially no autonomy within this course, so if you like to be spoon-fed then it is perfect.

The quizes often asked questions that required more knowledge of chemistry than was explained in the lab manual.  This made it very difficult for anyone taking the course who was not currently enrolled in a chemistry class, and I believe it also gave those enrolled in 163 an advantage of those in 161 since it was not simply based off what could be picked up by doing the pre-lab reading of the manual.

Weaknesses:
It was graded very poorly and unclearly. Some instructions were unclear. Professor was weak. Pre-lab quizzes were very difficult.
Strengths:
TAs were decent.

The experiments are structured well; however, the lab reports can be tedious and are extremely specific when it comes to grading, causing you to lose points for very small, often insignificant, details.

Strength: we learned so much about the lab, the resources, how to use them, and how to be proficient with our time. 
Weakness: I was not always prepared for the quizzes after lecture.

One strength of the course is that the labs taught me very useful skills I can use in chemistry labs. Another strength is that the course stuck to a very strict schedule, so I know what to expect in lab every week. One weakness of the course is that the grades seem to come from how well you adhere to the formatting rules of the lab report rather than the actual lab procedures/results. Another weakness is that the quizzes were unpredictable; most require you to memorize formulas or chemical equations that were in the lab procedures. An emphasis in the work that is produced from the actual lab rather than the formatting skills on the lab report will benefit future students.

I would recommend this class to someone who is interested in chemistry or science. But I would not recommend this class to someone who was not interested in the subject because it is very challenging and takes a lot of time.

Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to. Double and triple check your major requirements before signing up for CHEM 134L. It's an over-the-top workload 
for half of a credit. It's not worth it.
If you like labs and lab write ups then yes. However it is a lot of work
Short answer, yes.  It was a good learning experience, but make sure to ask for help early and often.

No one would recommend this course to another student. The happiest moment of my week as always walking out of SCL after lab and feeling that life would be enjoyable for the next few days before I had to start thinking about lab again. The importance placed on the prelab quizzes was nonsensical, I learned very little about actual lab techniques, and it was generally just a waste of my day. Dr. G is a petty grader with a petty rubric, routinely taking off large numbers of points for things completely irrelevant to any possible learning objectives. Just a general dumpster fire of a course.
I would not recommend this course to anyone. If you need it as a requirement then take it.

Don't take this class unless it is a requirement. The time commitment is ridiculous for a .5 credit class, since you have to put hours into each lab report to get an adequate grade and the class itself is 4 hours.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it is required for their major.
yes: it's important knowledge, and if you are willing to work hard and ask questions, you'll be fine.
It's certainly necessary but is sometimes more of a struggle than seems required

I would not recommend this class to another student. The amount of work that you will put into the class far exceeds any benefits you get from the class. Most of the people in the class are completely miserable and are only taking the class because they are required to for their major (or pre-med).
Yes, as it teaches basic lab technique necessary for higher courses.

I would not. If you have taken AP or IB Chemistry and done any lab work, you probably already have the skills that this class will teach you. Do not take it unless you absolutely have to for your major.

This is a great class if you need to get basic lab skills for future science endeavors. The lab reports are very daunting at first but about halfway through the semester they become second nature and do not take very long to complete. Dr. G is a very nice guy if you are respectful and follow the rules he sets in place, and is willing to help if you ask for it. However, the class really depends on whether or not you have a good TF as they are the ones monitoring you in the lab and grading most of your lab reports.
Yes, this lab is very well structured and if you follow Dr. G's instructions closely, you will be fine. Don't stress out!

Let's be real, this course is needed for medical school, so it's not like you are really going to get out of it unless you place into orgo. On that note, it will become blatantly clear that not only will you get points taken off for minutia in the lab reports, but that Yale has and will continue to do nothing to improve this laboratory course. Dr. G, bless his soul, should not be teaching undergraduate laboratory courses at Yale University. Please look at course reviews in the past and see just how much everyone absolutely hates the general chemistry lab sequence. This course gives a bad rep to Yale science; its that inane.

For pre-med students: I am truly sorry.
For non pre-med/non science: Get out while you can.
Only if required
I would recommend this course if it is a prerequisite and is necessary for your major or career path.

Take it if you have to. The reports are annoying, especially towards the beginning of the year, as they are long and tedious. You'll spend forever on them, but still somehow feel like you haven't actually done anything as many of them are pre-filled out for you. The experiments do get better by the end.

Yes, I would recommend this to any student seeking to either learn more about the basics of chem or working in a lab in general. I think it's the most essential intro class I have taken so far, and it is the one I have learned the most from.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in the sciences and needs experience working in a chemical lab. It is indeed more comprehensive than a high school lab course and we do learn a lot. However, it is a lot of work and those coming into the class must be prepared for the common sentiment that "lab classes are half the credit yet double the work."
Yes, it was a good way to learn how to do simple procedures that will be useful later on in all kinds of labs.
Only if you have to take it.
I assume that if you are taking the lab it is because you need to take it. The course is very time consuming, and definitely worth more than half a credit.

I would not recommend this course to a student unless they are required to take it. It takes up a lot of time for only 0.5 credits, and I don't think what you learn is particularly useful or relevant. A lot of those same skills can be learned in an actual lab setting. Moreover, it doesn't help a lot with learning chemistry concepts.
Yes, so long as they're willing to put the time and work required to do well.
I would recommend this course to a student who wants to develop lab skills and be able to participate in such activities independently.
As I am sure will be a consistent theme concerning this course, only take it if it is required. Safe yourself the agony.
I would not recommend this course unless the student absolutely had to take it. It is a frustrating class that is emotionally draining.
I would recommend this course to a student looking to build on basic lab skills or to fulfill requirements.
I would not recommend taking this course unless you have to. If you want to take a lab, try a different one.
The student must be very familiar with chemistry and lab equipment to be successful.
NOPE. Unless you need it, don't take it.
No.
Only if you had to take this course for your degree would I take it.

Yes. I would warn them that it is really hard and a lot of work though

I would recommend general chemistry lab to another student. I think that it's a good opportunity for students to familiarize themselves with some basic lab techniques. I would also tell the student to be prepared for a lot of self-directed learning and work in terms of lab reports.
I wouldn't recommend this course to another student unless they needed to take it. it is a lot of work and takes up a lot more time than other full credit courses.
If you do not have to take chem lab, then do not do it. A lot of work goes into the lab reports.

Yes, I would recommend the course if it is required as a prerequisite. You will learn basic chemistry lab skills that will be important for future lab courses as well, but more importantly, you will learn to be very meticulous in the work that you do. The TAs are very important in making this course more manageable, as they are open to giving feedback and answering questions. Always ask questions if you need help.

It was a lot of time and more effort than half a credit should be, but all you potential premeds out there are probably better getting it out of the way now because you will have to take it eventually.
I would absolutely recommend this class to a motivated student who is willing to reach out for help and guidance.
I would recommend it only if you need it to satisfy your requirements but it is definitely not a class I will take for fun.

no.

I would only recommend this class if it is something you have to take for your major.

I recommend this course because it is required by a lot of majors. If it is not required for a major or if a student is not considering a future working in a lab, many skills in this course are not very applicable. Still, some concepts in lab did help with my understanding of content in Gen Chem.
NOOOOO!!! Take freshman orgo

Don't take this unless you have to.

I find it hard to imagine anyone enrolling in this class just for the fun of it.  That being said, you do have to do Chem lab while enrolled in the Chem lecture course, so be careful about dropping it if it's a requirement for your major. DO NOT take this course unless it is REQUIRED OF YOU. You probably already know how to read, follow a procedure, and fill in some blanks, so you will not gain anything from this class.
Not unless it's required for your major, which it most likely is
I can't recommend this course to another student because everybody takes this for their prereqs. So it's fine I'm fine everything is fine.
I WOULD NOT under any circumstance, besides if it is required of course, recommend this course to any student!
I would recommend it if you are interested in chemistry and want to learn lab skills, or obviously if it is a requirement for a certain STEM major.

Take it if you have to. Do not is you can avoid it. It is a very stressful class, but make friends, be nice to your TF and absolutely do not be afraid to ask Dr. G or your TF if you have any questions at all about your lab!

It is a lab class that is required at the basic level of chemistry. While the class was enjoyable, it is difficult to understand the instructor's standards for the lab report, resulting in initially low grades.

no if it wasnt required

I only really recommend this course if you are required to take it due to being pre-med or because you have to for your major. The course is very strenuous and requires a large amount of dedication in order to do well.

Yes this course is essential to obtain knowledge about conducting experiments properly.

I would recommend this course to another student, as it builds on the fundamentals of chemistry and allows students to apply what they have learned.

I would recommend this course to a student because many valuable insights are learn through this expierence.

It can help you figure out if you want to pursue the science yourself, or if you just find it fascinating. There are some really cool experiments done here, for sure.
If you need to take it, then take it. I would not recommend it if you're looking for a credit outside your major.

I would only recommend this course to another student if you need it for your major (or one of many prospective majors). This course will eat away your soul, and you should only give up your soul if you need to take this course for your major. I would not understand why someone would take this lab course if it weren't for your major. I though it would be enjoyable, since I enjoyed my junior college chemistry lab, but this class is totally different. Don't be like me and suffer for no reason: make sure you get your priorities in check before enrolling (and you could probably take this lab next time if you do not think it is for your major). Also, plan to spend $45-60 on student lab notebook and lab coat (unless you can find others on the free and for sale Facebook group).
I would only recommend this course if you need this course for your major.

If you plan on going into something that requires labs then it would be important to  take labs like this. However, if not, labs take a lot of time and if you aren't interested, it would be very difficult to stay focused.

Take this class if you need it. Do not take it if you are trying to get a science credit.

This is the worst class I have taken at Yale. Labs were boring and stressful and lab reports were tedious. Grading was extremely arbitrary at times. One of my pre-lab quiz grades was lowered by 15% because I used pencil instead of pen. I think the main thing I learned was how to format graphs in excel and type using the equation editor in microsoft word. Grading on lab reports is mainly based on if you used the correct number of sigfigs. Beware.

If you don't need to have Gen Chem lab for your major, don't take it. The lab reports are very time consuming (even if you don't procrastinate) and are graded relatively harshly for the most part (5 points off for small errors), and yet the course only counts for half a credit.
No, but it's a requirement for a lot of students.
No. It was a terrible experience that wreaked havoc on my mental health.

No, but if youre pre-med you kind of dont have a choice if you havent skipped to Organic Chemistry.

If you dont have to, dont take this course. It is a lot of work for only 1/2 credit.

I would recommend this course to another student. Although it is certainly challenging and requires a lot of work to do well, I believe that this course will help students work well in challenging situations. It also encourages problem solving and cooperation.
People should only take this course if they are 100% positive that they need it for their major/ premedical track. It takes a huge chunk of dedication and time.

No  only take this course as a prereq for a particular major/med school. The intro classes should be encouraging students to continue with lab classes even if they havent had previous lab experience.
No, not unless you're required to for pre-med/major.
Yes if necessary for future classes or medical school.

If you do not need to take this course, do not take this course! This class has been known to kill GPAs and will deflate the actual grade you have in the class. The four-hour labs are terrible to work into your schedule. For the first few weeks, Dr. G grades the lab reports with strict grading guidelines and gives little feedback to correct your mistakes. After those weeks, your grade will (hopefully) be better as your TA will start to grade the lab reports.
